text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

These guidelines have been established for handling delinquent Forms 1120-F (which includes a protective Form 1120-F as described in Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(vi)) and requests for waiver pursuant to Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(ii).
ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM incorporates Interim Guidance Memorandum LB&I-04-0120-0003, originally issued as 0218-007, LB&I Guidelines for Handling Delinquent Forms 1120-F and Requests for Waiver Pursuant to Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(ii).
Primarily LB&I managers, examiners and specialists, may also apply to some SB/SE and W&I personnel.
Handling Delinquent Forms
-F and Requests (
) Purpose: This IRM provides the guidance and procedures to be followed handling delinquent Forms
-F and requests for waiver pursuant to Reg.
)(ii) that have been established to ensure that these delin- quent tax returns and requests for waiver are handled by managers, agents, examiners and specialists in a consistent manner. (

) Audience: These procedures and guidance apply to all revenue agents/ examiners in the Large Business and International Division (LB&I) and their direct managers (examination team). These procedures may also apply to examiners in Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) and Wage and Invest- ment (W&I). (
) Policy Owner: Director, Cross Border Activities (CBA) Practice Area, LB&I. (
) Program Owner: The CBA practice network manages and administers this guidance. (
) Primary Stakeholders: IRS managers, revenue agents, examiners and cialists in LB&I, SB/SE and W&I. (
) Program Goals: Ensure that delinquent Forms
-F returns ﬁled with requests are analyzed in a fair, consistent and timely manner under Treas. Reg.
) A foreign corporation is required to ﬁle Form
-F if it is engaged in a trade or business. The Form
-F must be ﬁled at the location the instructions to Form
-F (U.S. Income Tax Return of a Foreign tion), whether or not the return is timely ﬁled for purposes of Treas. Reg.
) In general, if the foreign corporation fails to ﬁle Form
-F before the of the date of notiﬁcation by the IRS that a return is due or
months after due date under IRC
, it is not entitled to deductions and credits under
) and the regulations thereunder, and will instead be subject to tax under IRC
on its gross income at the rate provided for the applicable tax year. (
) Treas. Reg.

)(ii) permits the Commissioner to waive the ﬁling deadline, and thus allow the foreign corporation to claim deductions and credits, if the foreign corporation can establish, based on the facts and stances, that it acted reasonably and in good faith in failing to timely ﬁle a return. (
) No one involved in a compliance function should accept as ﬁled a return from a taxpayer (except as provided in the IRM) or discuss in of ﬁling a return whether a waiver will be granted. (
) Once a return is ﬁled, and the return is selected for examination, the in this IRM shall apply. (
) Unless otherwise noted, any reference to a Form
-F in this IRM protective Form
-F as described in Treas. Reg.
Guidelines for Handling Delinquent Forms 1120-F and Requests for Waiver 4.61.14 page 1
Unless otherwise noted, any reference to a Form 1120-F in this IRM includes protective Form 1120-F as described in Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(iv).

) All waiver requests are granted or denied by the authority of the Deputy missioner, LB&I under Treas. Reg.
)(ii) pursuant to LB&I DO
) Without prejudice to prior determinations, the Deputy Commissioner has delegated this authority to the Directors of Field Operations (DFO), Cross Border Activities (CBA). (
) Accordingly, the procedures below set forth the manner in which waiver requests will be elevated to the DFO for a ﬁnal determination. (
) No one involved in a compliance function should accept as ﬁled a Form
-F (see exception below) from a taxpayer or discuss in advance ﬁling a return whether a waiver will be granted. (
) If a taxpayer or a taxpayer’s representative submits a delinquent Form or discusses the likelihood of a waiver being granted from the ﬁling for the delinquent Form
-F, the examination team should inform the taxpayer (or its representative) that the Form
-F, even though under Treas. Reg.
)(i), must be ﬁled in accordance with the instructions for the Form
) Once a return is ﬁled, and selected for examination, the examination team develop any requests for waiver in accordance with the waiver request lines. (

) If the taxpayer did not submit a request for waiver for the tax return for examination, the examination team should make the taxpayer aware in writing of the option to request a waiver under Treas. Reg.
)(ii) shall not advise, instruct or otherwise signal the taxpayer to take any action. See Exhibit

-F. If the return is secured as provided under (

) The CBA Practice Area program manager will conduct ad hoc Waiver dures program reviews as necessary to verify compliance with IRM requirements, address Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) and/or Government Accountability Office (GAO) ﬁndings and support for any trends that appear. (
) Case reviews are conducted by the territory manager and the team to ensure compliance with this IRM. (
) The CBA DFO determines whether to grant or deny the request for waiver based only on the waiver request package and recommendations from the Waiver Committee.

Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accordance with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, see https://www.irs.gov/ taxpayer-bill-of-rights.
International Examination (
) Under IRC

), a foreign corporation that is engaged in a trade or business within the United States is only allowed deductions and credits that are connected with income that is effectively connected with the conduct of trade or business (“ECI”). Those deductions and credits are further on the foreign corporation ﬁling a true and accurate return in the manner required by subtitle F, including all the information necessary for the of such deductions and credits. These conditions do not apply to credits provided by IRC
for tax withheld at source or to deductions for charitable contributions allowed under IRC
, whether or not connected to ECI. (
) IRC
provides the due dates for foreign corporations required to ﬁle an income tax return (Form

-F). The due date depends on whether the foreign corporation has an office or place of business in the United States. If does have such an office or place of business, the return is due at the same time as a return of a domestic corporation. Note that those due dates for tax years beginning on or after January
If it does not have such office or place of business, the return is due on or before the
th day of the
th month after the close of its taxable or ﬁscal year. (
) Under Treas. Reg.

) a foreign corporation is required to ﬁle a return if it is engaged in a U.S. trade or business, even if it has no ECI or its income is exempt from tax under a tax treaty. However, if the foreign tion has no gross income for the taxable year, it is not required to complete return schedules, but must attach a statement indicating the nature of any clusions claimed and the amount of the exclusions, to the extent such are readily determinable. (
) Form
-F returns should be ﬁled in accordance with the Form
-F instructions. Currently, Form
-F returns are ﬁled with the Internal Service Center in Ogden, UT. Taxpayers may also be able to ﬁle Form returns electronically. Prior to
, Form
-F returns were ﬁled with the Internal Revenue Service Center in Philadelphia, PA. (
) The table below provides an illustrative example of the ﬁling deadlines as described above (under IRC
and Treas. Reg.
) based on the corporation maintains an office or ﬁxed place of business in the United States and its tax year end.

Treas. Reg.

)(i) prevents a foreign corporation from receiving the beneﬁt of deductions and credits otherwise allowable (with the exceptions for deductions and credits noted in the statute) if it fails to meet the following special ﬁling dates, as applicable, set forth in the regulations:
(06-08-2020) Special Filing Deadlines for Foreign Corporations Under IRC 882(c)(2)

a. If a return was ﬁled for the immediately preceding taxable year, or if the current taxable year is the ﬁrst taxable year of the foreign corporation for which a return is required to be ﬁled, the required return for the current taxable year must be ﬁled within
months of the due date as set forth in IRC

and the regulations under that section. b. If no return for the taxable year immediately preceding the current taxable year has been ﬁled, the required return for the current taxable year (other than the ﬁrst taxable year of the foreign corporation for which a return is required to be ﬁled) must have been ﬁled no later than the earlier of the date which is
months after the due date, as per IRC

, for ﬁling the return for the current taxable year or the date the IRS mails a notice to the foreign corporation advising the corporation that the current year tax return has not been ﬁled and that no deductions or credits (other than those excepted by statute) may be claimed by the taxpayer.
) Under Treas. Reg. §

)(vi), a foreign corporation that conducts limited activities in the United States that it determines do not give rise to ECI may nonetheless ﬁle a return for the taxable year on a timely basis under Treas. Reg.

)(i) to protect its right to receive the beneﬁt of deduc- tions and credits if it is later determined, after the return is ﬁled, that the determination is incorrect. The return does not need to report any gross income as ECI or any deductions or credits but should include a statement the return is being ﬁled to protect the foreign corporation’s right to deductions and credits. A foreign corporation may follow the same procedure if it deter- mines initially that it has no U.S. tax liability under the provisions of an applicable income tax treaty. If it is claiming it does not have a permanent es- tablishment in the United States, it must also generally disclose that position on Form

) The examination team will review and analyze the taxpayer’s waiver request and make a recommendation on whether to grant or deny the waiver request based on all facts and circumstances, including those provided in the taxpay- er’s request. The examination team will prepare the “Waiver Request (described in paragraph (
) below) and forward the recommendation for tance or denial to the territory manager along with the package. (
) The Waiver Request Package includes the administrative ﬁle including, but limited to: a. The Waiver Summary Analysis (see Exhibit

). b. The taxpayer’s request for waiver and any supplements thereto. c. Any IDRs or other requests for information related to the request for waiver issued by the examination team to the taxpayer or third-parties. d. The responses to any such IDRs and requests for information. e. A Form
-A, protest and rebuttal, if any. f. Documentation to support that the procedures are followed (as outlined this IRM section).
See Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(iii) for illustrative examples.

This process will continue until the examination team and the territory come to a recommendation to send forth to the appropriate CBA DFO area staff assistant (staff assistant). (

) The processing of the examination team’s recommendation on a request for waiver differs depending on whether the examination team, with the concur- rence of the territory manager, recommends that the waiver request be (see IRM
) or denied (see IRM
). See Exhibit for the ﬂowchart of the procedures. (

) If the examination team, with the concurrence of the territory manager, mends that a request for a waiver be granted, the territory manager will That a forward the waiver request package to the appropriate staff assistant. for Waiver Be (

) Once the staff assistant conﬁrms that the waiver request package is they will forward the waiver request package to the CBA DFO for their nation to grant or deny the request for waiver. Follow paragraph (
) below if the CBA DFO agrees with the examination team’s assessment. Otherwise, follow paragraphs (
) and (
) below. (

) If the CBA DFO agrees with the examination team’s recommendation and termines that the waiver should be granted, the staff assistant will communicate the determination to the territory manager and the team manager, as well as to the Waiver Committee. The examination team will sequently notify the taxpayer in writing of the determination. (

) If the CBA DFO does not agree with the recommendation to grant the the CBA DFO has the option to request additional information, and consult the Waiver Committee in order to reach a ﬁnal decision. (

) The staff assistant will communicate the CBA DFO’s ﬁnal determination to grant or deny the waiver) to the territory manager and team manager, as well as the Waiver Committee. The examination team will subsequently the taxpayer in writing of the determination. (

) If the examination team, with the concurrence of the territory manager, mends that a request for waiver be denied, the territory manager will forward That a the waiver request package to the staff assistant. for Waiver Be (
) Once the staff assistant conﬁrms that the waiver request package is they will forward the waiver request package to the Waiver Committee as described in IRM
for its consideration (with a copy to the CBA DFO). (
) The Waiver Committee will ensure that, regardless of the type of business conducted, all recommendations for denial of waivers will be evaluated by independent committee and handled consistently. (
) The staff assistant will schedule a conference call with the Waiver the examination team and the territory manager to discuss the case.

) The team manager on the Waiver Committee will forward the waiver recom- mendation, or recommendations (if the Waiver Committee and the team still disagree) and the waiver request package, to the staff assistant. (

) The staff assistant will submit the recommendation(s) to the CBA DFO. The CBA DFO may request additional information or clariﬁcation from the Waiver Committee and/or examination team prior to making their determination. (

) The staff assistant will communicate the CBA DFO’s ﬁnal determination to the territory manager, team manager and the Waiver Committee. The team will subsequently notify the taxpayer in writing of the determination. (

contains scenarios to illustrate these procedures.

The staff assistant will communicate the CBA DFO’s ﬁnal determination to the territory manager, team manager and the Waiver Committee. The examination team will subsequently notify the taxpayer in writing of the determination.

Did the corporation cooperate in the process of determining its income tax liability for the taxable year for the return was not ﬁled?

Additionally, consider the following factors in determining whether the foreign corporation, based on the facts and circumstances, acted reasonably and in good faith in failing to ﬁle a U.S. income tax return:

Reg. Factor Section (A) Whether the corporation voluntarily identiﬁes itself to the Internal Revenue Service as having failed to ﬁle a U.S. income tax return before the Internal Revenue Service discovers the failure to ﬁle. (B) Whether the corporation did not become aware of its ability to ﬁle a protective return (as described in paragraph (a)(

)(vi) of this section) by the deadline for ﬁling a protective return. (C) Whether the corporation had not previously ﬁled a U.S. income tax return. (D) Whether the corporation failed to ﬁle a U.S. income tax return because, after exercising reasonable diligence (taking into account its relevant experience and level of sophistica- tion), the corporation was unaware of the necessity for ﬁling the return. (E) Whether the corporation failed to ﬁle a U.S. income tax return because of intervening events beyond its control. (F) Whether other mitigating or exacerbating factors existed.

Guidelines for Handling Delinquent Forms 1120-F and Requests for Waiver 4.61.14 page Exhibit 4.61.14-3 (06-08-2020) Scenarios

Scenario 1: A taxpayer not currently under exam approaches the IRS (e.g., examiner, revenue agent or special- ist) directly and informs the IRS that for a particular tax year it has not ﬁled a Form 1120-F for which the relevant timely ﬁling deadline under Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(i) has passed, and that it now seeks to ﬁle a de- linquent Form 1120-F. In some instances, a taxpayer representative may approach the IRS on a no-name basis on behalf of a taxpayer. The taxpayer or representative may seek to submit a delinquent return to the IRS or discuss the likelihood of a waiver being granted from the ﬁling deadlines for the delinquent Form 1120-F.

In Scenario 1, the IRS should inform the taxpayer (or its representative, as applicable) that the Form 1120-F, even though delinquent under Treas. Reg. 1.882- 4(a)(3)(i), must be ﬁled in accordance with the ﬁling instruc- tions for the Form 1120-F. Also in Scenario 1, the IRS should not accept a delinquent Form 1120-F from the taxpayer or accept from, or discuss with, the taxpayer a request for waiver pursuant to Treas. Reg. § 1.882- 4(a)(3)(ii).

Scenario 2. An examiner, revenue agent or specialist (examination team) has been assigned the examination of a ﬁled Form 1120-F for a particular tax year and determines that the ﬁling of the Form 1120-F failed to meet the relevant timely ﬁling deadline under Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(i).
In Scenario 2, the steps that the IRS should take depend on whether the taxpayer has submitted a request waiver pursuant to Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(ii).
The examination team should develop the facts relevant to the request for waiver in accordance with Treas. Reg.
)(ii), reach a recom- mendation to grant or deny the request and then follow the process set forth in IRM
The examination team should develop the facts relevant to the request in accordance with Treas. Reg.
)(ii), reach a recommendation to grant or deny the request and then follow the process set forth in under IRM
, above.
Exhibit 4.61.14-3 (Cont. 1) (06-08-2020) Scenarios

Note: Regardless of the determination on a request for waiver, the examination team may, as appropriate, propose to disallow speciﬁc deductions and credits in any amount to the extent that they are determined to be not allowable under the law or have not been properly substantiated.
Guidelines for Handling Delinquent Forms 1120-F and Requests for Waiver 4.61.14 page 15
Exhibit 4.61.14-4 (06-08-2020) Wording to Use With Waiver Procedure Information Letter
[IRS contact]

Revenue Code section 882(c)(2) and Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(2) provide that a foreign corporation is deductions properly allocated and apportioned to effectively connected income and credits attributable

Internal Revenue Code section 882(c)(2) and Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(2) provide that a foreign corporation is allowed deductions properly allocated and apportioned to effectively connected income and credits attributable to that income only if it timely ﬁles a true and accurate return of its taxable income which is effectively connected, or treated as effectively connected, with the conduct of a United States trade or business for the taxable year (Exceptions apply for the deductions allowed under section 170 and credits provided by sections 33, 34 and 852(b)(3)(D)(ii)). The return, on Form 1120-F, must be ﬁled in accordance with the Form 1120-F ﬁling instructions. The current ﬁling instructions provide that the Form 1120-F return must be ﬁled with the Internal Revenue Service Center in Ogden, UT.

Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(i) sets forth the speciﬁc ﬁling deadlines for ﬁling a true and accurate return of a foreign corporation for purposes of determining allowance of the deductions and credits described above. Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(ii) provides that the ﬁling deadlines may be waived if the foreign corporation establishes to the satisfaction of the Commissioner or his or her delegate that the corporation, based on the facts and circum- stances, acted reasonably and in good faith in failing to ﬁle a U.S. income tax return (including a protective return). For this purpose, a foreign corporation shall not be considered to have acted reasonably and in good faith if it knew that it was required to ﬁle the return and chose not to do so. Please note that under these regula- tions “a foreign corporation shall not be granted a waiver unless it cooperates in the process of determining its income tax liability for the taxable year for which the return was not ﬁled.”

Treas. Reg. 1.882-4(a)(3)(i) sets forth the speciﬁc ﬁling deadlines for ﬁling a true and accurate return of a foreign corporation for purposes of determining allowance of the deductions and credits described above.
